source.2faa187b:
#Vector of 16 available gouvernorates
Tunisia = [Beja,Bizerte,Gafsa,Jendouba,Kairouan,Kef,Mahdia,Mednine,Monastir,Nabeul,Sfax,SidiBouzid,Siliana,Sousse,Tataouine,Zaghouan]

#Create a function that retrieve the name of any variable
def retrieve_name(var):
    callers_local_vars = inspect.currentframe().f_back.f_locals.items()
    return [var_name for var_name, var_val in callers_local_vars if var_val is var][0]

#Create a function that a gouvernorate column 
def add_gouvernorate(Gov,name):
    Gov['Gouvernorate'] = np.repeat(name,len(Gov))
source.790e45fc:
#Add 'Gouvernorate' column
Gov = Tunisia[0]
for Gov in Tunisia:
    name = retrieve_name(Gov)
    add_gouvernorate(Gov,name)

#Line plot of the surface(m²) for each gouvernorate
    #NB : You can plot any other variable by switching y value
%matplotlib inline
matplotlib.rcParams['figure.figsize']=[12,10]
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
p = df.groupby('Gouvernorate').plot(x='Year', y='Surface m2', ax=ax)
plt.legend(np.unique(df['Gouvernorate']))
source.5a234d33:
import plotly.plotly as py
import plotly.graph_objs as go

# Create traces
Gov = [Beja,Bizerte,Gafsa,Jendouba,Kairouan,Kef,Mahdia,Mednine,Monastir,Nabeul,Sfax,SidiBouzid,Siliana,Sousse,Tataouine,Zaghouan]
p = []
for i in range(1,len(Gov)):
    a = go.Scatter(
        x = Gov[i]['Year'].values,
        y = Gov[i]['Surface m2'].values,
        mode = 'lines+markers',
        name = retrieve_name(Gov[i]))
    p.append(a)

sns.heatmap(corr, 
            square=True,
            mask = mask ,
            vmax = .3,
            linewidths=.5,            
            cbar_kws={"shrink": .5},
            xticklabels=corr.columns,
            yticklabels=corr.columns)
source.a4cfd08f:
Presentation

The solar photovoltaic market has experienced a very strong growth since the end of the 90s. The significant and continuous evolution of the global production of photovoltaic modules has allowed this industry to acquire a technological maturity and a continuous decline in production costs of the modules. Given the promising prospect of solar photovoltaics, Tunisia is seeking to develop applications connected to the network of this technology at the national level, especially since it has favorable sun conditions and a good experience feedback through projects carried out in the field of rural electrification and the pumping of water by solar energy. To this end, a regulatory and incentive framework has been put in place. This framework states:

  1. The authorization of the residential sector and establishments and groups of establishments operating in the industrial, agricultural or tertiary sectors to produce electricity for their own consumption from solar photovoltaic energy while benefiting from the right to sell surplus electricity. electric energy produced at the Tunisian Company of Electricity and Gas
  2. The establishment of a 30% premium of the cost of the investment with a ceiling of three thousand dinars (3,000 TnD) per kilowatt peak of power and fifteen thousand dinars (15,000 TnD) per photovoltaic installation
Moreover and in order to ensure the conditions allowing the diffusion of the solar buildings in the residential sector, Tunisia has set up the project 'PROSOL ELEC' which relies on an incentive mechanism inspired by that of the PROSOL project which brought about a real change scale of solar water heating market.

Benefits granted under 'PROSOL ELEC'

The PROSOL ELEC mechanism provides a set of incentives targeting residential customers of 'STEG' wishing to equip themselves with photovoltaic solar installations to partially cover their electrical energy needs. These incentives consist of:

  • A grant from the National Fund for the Control of Energy (NFCE) representing 30% of the cost of the investment of the photovoltaic installation and capped at 3,000 dinars per kWp
  • An additional premium of 10% of the cost of the investment granted by the Italian Ministry of the Environment and Territory (IMET) through the MEDiterranean Renewable Energy Center (MEDREC)
  • A 5-year credit of up to 3,000 dinars per kWp, granted by 'Ettijari Bank' and repayable on the 'STEG' invoice
  • An improvement of the total interest rate of the credit, equivalent to a premium of 5% of the cost of the investment, served by the 'IMET'.

Objective of the project

The objective of the 'PROSOL ELEC' project is to build around 1,000 solar buildings with a total photovoltaic power of 1,500 kW.

Beneficiaries eligible for the project

Eligible for the 'PROSOL ELEC' project, any residential client that meets the following conditions:

  • Be the owner of the premises to be equipped and have a low voltage subscription 'STEG' in his name and valid
  • Having a minimum annual power consumption of 2,000 kWh for 1 kW solar installations and 4,000 kWh for 2 kW solar installations
  • Having a sufficient surface that can support the equipment.

    Permissible powers of photovoltaic systems

    In accordance with the regulations, the power of a photovoltaic installation connected to the network to be carried out by a beneficiary, must not exceed the power contracted of this one with the 'STEG'. However, for reasons related to the choice of inverters and the budget available for granting the surcharge and credit enhancement, the powers eligible under the 'PROSOL ELEC' project will be 1 or 2 kWp. People wishing to have a higher power, could benefit in addition to the benefits set for 'PROSOL ELECTRICAL' within the limit of 2 kWp, the grant of the NFCE without its overall amount does not exceed 15 000 TnD.

    Source: http://www.steg.com.tn/fr/prosol_elec/presentation.html

Name :

Available Gouvernorates :

Beja , Bizerte , Gafsa , Jendouba , Kairouan , Kef , Mahdia , Mednine , Monastir , Nabeul , Sfax , SidiBouzid , Siliana , Sousse , Tataouine , Zaghouan
